explanation: The report is correct. In lfs_init the code assigns lfs->lookahead.buffer = lfs->cfg->lookahead_buffer when the user supplies one, but there is no runtime check that the object pointed to by cfg->lookahead_buffer is at least cfg->lookahead_size bytes. The struct comment documents the requirement (“Must be lookahead_size”), but that is only a caller contract and there is no proof in the code that the supplied buffer meets that size. Later code in the library is expected to operate on the lookahead buffer using the configured size (e.g. zeroing or copying lookahead_size bytes with memset/memcpy or similar operations). If the caller provides a smaller buffer, those standard string/memory functions would access beyond the bounds of the object referenced by the pointer parameter, which is exactly what MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 forbids. (Using LFS_ASSERT or relying on documentation does not constitute a proof that the object has the required size at runtime.)
